newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: India cancels term LPG tender, reappraises needs.
newsitem.headline: India cancels term LPG tender, reappraises needs.

text.p: State-owned Indian Oil Corp (IOC) has cancelled a one-year term tender for 540,000 tonnes of liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) and is reappraising its import needs, a source close to the company said on Friday.
IOC had tendered to buy 18 cargoes, each consisting 25,000-tonnes of butane and 5,000-tonnes of propane, between July 1997 and June 1998.
The tender was due to close May 27.
"It was cancelled because the requirement was not there," the source said. "IOC has plans to issue a new one-year term tender but the details are still being worked out."

India's oil industry has been thrown into uncertainty this month by junior Petroleum Minister T.R. Balu recommending a 15-20 percent hike in state-controlled prices of LPG and diesel, to pay money owed to oil companies accrued from selling subsidised petroleum products below market prices.
The debt or oil pool deficit, totalled 155 billion rupees ($4.33 billion) at the end of March and is expected to rise to 245 billion rupees by March 31 1998.

To release the government from the financial burden of providing subsidies on LPG, the government in February 1993 liberalised imports and distribution of non-subsidised LPG by introducing a "parallel marketing" scheme.
But imports, and consequently consumption - at around 4.2 million tonnes-per-year - were being capped by inadequate port and terminalling facilities, which are mostly state-owned.
Public sector companies have an annual import capacity of 1.9 million tonnes, IOC official said.
As a result, IOC still dominates the market as it imports LPG on behalf of public sector companies which then supply consumers at subsidised prices.

IOC imports LPG on both a spot and a term basis, but other than an outstanding term contract with Saudi Aramco for 13,000-tonnes between January and December, it has not imported any term cargoes since its last term contract expired in March, the source said.
